Quick Walk Through the World of Location & Places APIs

Photo Credits

I took a walk through what I am calling the locations and places API landscape today. Most of these APIs Iâ€™m familiar with, but as the CityGrid API Evangelist, Iâ€™m getting an opportunity to immerse myself into this new local, social mobile world.

As I immerse myself in this semi-new world I want to share my findings with everyone else. Â If you have any suggestions make sure and let me know in comments below.

First I started withÂ CityGrid APIs, which provide several key location and places APIs:

  • The Places APIÂ - Provides functionality for information on local businesses, including search, detail, user content submission, and predictive text
  • The Offers APIÂ - Provides coupons and special offers from businesses based on geography and category
  • The Reviews APIÂ - Provides access to customer reviews for businesses selected by id or by geography or category

Then I wanted to see what Google was doing, and of course started with theÂ Google Maps APIs:

  • Maps JavaScript APIÂ - The Google Maps Javascript API lets you embed Google Maps in your own web pages
  • Maps Image APIÂ - The Google Maps Image APIs make it easy to embed a static Google Maps image or Street View panorama into your web page, with no need for JavaScript

Along with Google Maps they offer a set ofÂ Geo Web ServicesÂ that contain several location and places based APIs:

  • Directions APIÂ - The Google Directions API is a service that calculates directions between locations
  • Distance Matrix APIÂ - The Google Distance Matrix API is a service that provides travel distance and time for a matrix of origins and destinations.
  • Elevation APIÂ - The Google Elevation API provides you an interface to query locations on the earth for elevation data.
  • Geocoding APIÂ - Geocoding is the process of converting addresses into geographic coordinates
  • Places APIÂ - The Google Places API is a service that returns information about places, defined as establishments, geographic locations, or prominent points of interest

Already withÂ CityGridÂ and Google Iâ€™m seeing that the type of location and places services, really start to get complicated and diverse. WithÂ Google LatitudeÂ I start separating the location from the place, with what are two location specific APIs:

  • Curent locationsÂ - Represents the userâ€™s most recent known location
  • Location historyÂ - Represents the list of all recorded user locations

After Google I have to look at another big player,Â Yahoo. Yahoo has several location based services:

  • Fire EagleÂ - Fire Eagle is a service designed to build and use location-aware applications and services
  • GeoPlanetÂ - Yahoo! GeoPlanet is a resource for managing all geo-permanent named places on Earth
  • LocalÂ APIÂ - Provides a database of information including business address and phone, category, rating, distance, URL, and traffic alerts
  • MapsÂ - Provides interactive maps with driving directions and traffic information
  • PlaceFinderÂ - Converts street addresses or place names into geographic coordinates (and vice versa)
  • PlacemakerÂ - Identifies places mentioned in text, disambiguating them and returning unique identifiers

Naturally after taking a look at Yahoo I have to go see whatÂ MicrosoftÂ is up to in the space:

  • Bing Maps API- The API that power Bing Maps, an online mapping service that enables users to search, discover, explore, plan, and share information about specific locations
  • Bings Maps Location APIÂ - Use the Locations API to get location information (I love this description!)

After looking at what local and mobile offerings the big players Google, Yahoo and Microsoft had I started looking at less search and mapping based services to more carrier based location and place services. I started withÂ Verizon, who has a single location API:

  • LBS Network APIÂ - The Verizon LBS API allows you to use the userâ€™s location to deliver specific services

SprintÂ brings three location APIs to the table:

  • GeofenceÂ - Provides virtual perimeter services
  • LocationÂ - Determines the location of a Sprint CDMA Device
  • PresenceÂ - Determines if a device is present on the Sprint CDMAÂ network

AT&TÂ has a LBS API:

  • Terminal LocationÂ - Set of Location-based Services (LBS)

Deutsche TelekomÂ has one location API:

  • IP Location APIÂ - Locate Internet users with their IP addresses

Ericsson LabsÂ provides a developer community around a full suite of APIS:

  • 3D Landscape APIÂ - 3D Landscape API for integration o realistic 3D MAPS
  • Mobile Location APIÂ - Allows the use a mobile phone userâ€™s current CELL-ID to obtain their geographical location
  • Network Probe APIÂ - Provides services measure certain characteristics of network IP connectivity, firewalls and Network Address Translators
  • Web Location APIÂ - Provides location data from a mobile phone using the positioning systems of mobile operators
  • Web Maps APIÂ - Provides dynamic maps for application integration

France TelecomÂ also has a location API:

  • Location APIÂ - Allows applications to get geographic coordinates of a given Orange France mobile phone or a fleet

Makes sense for every carrier to also provide developers with a set of location services, as they donâ€™t want to just be dumb pipes. They want to be an integrated player in their own customers handset usage.

Next I start looking to put the social in local, mobile, social. Where else to you start but Facebook, which has two location based objects as part of theÂ Graph API:

  • CheckinÂ - A checkin represents a single visit by a user to a location
  • PlacesÂ - A search option before initiating a checkin, returning name and location information from Graph API

I thought Iâ€™d consider Twitter next. Â They haveÂ Places and GeoÂ methods, but it really doesnâ€™t seem like its going anywhere, and a really small portion of tweets have geo info recorded. Â I will consider in the future if I see action around it.

In the category of location based social network I was investigatingÂ FoursquareÂ andÂ Gowalla, but with the recent Facebook acquisition of Gowalla I think I will only look atÂ Foursquare. Foursquare offers access to four different APIs:

  • Core APIÂ - Users, Venues, Venue Groups, Checkins, Tips, Lists, Photos, Specials, Campaigns, Events
  • Real-time APIÂ - Notifies venue managers when users check in to their venues, and our user push API notifies developers when their users check in anywhere
  • Merchant PlatformÂ - The Merchant Platform allows developers to write applications that help registered venue owners manage their foursquare presence and specials
  • Venues PlatformÂ - The Venues Platform allows developers to search for places and access a wealth of information about them, including addresses, popularity, tips, and photos

After Foursquare you leave social, getting into the places data world, with popular playerÂ SimpleGeo. Similar to Gowalla I was going to overlook SimpleGeo, with their recentÂ acquisition by Urban Airship, but I think SimpleGeo is still an important enough of a player, that we should still consider them in the game. SimpleGeo has four distinct web services for location and places:

  • SimpleGeo StorageÂ - Storage of data in SimpleGeo system
  • SimpleGeo FeaturesÂ - Features in SimpleGeo represent real-world places such as businesses, regions, or US states
  • SimpleGeo ContextÂ - Provides relevant contextual information such as weather, demographics, or neighborhood data for a specific location
  • SimpleGeo PlacesÂ - Businesses and points of interest

In the pure places data game Iâ€™d putÂ FactualÂ in the same category as SimpleGeo. Factual has seven location and places APIs:

  • Places Category APIÂ - Taxonomy to classify entities in the various Factual point-of-interest (POI) datasets
  • Places CrossrefÂ APIÂ - URLs for pages that mention a specific business or point of interest or vice versa
  • Places CrosswalkÂ APIÂ - Maps third-party (Yelp, Foursquare, etc.) identifiers for businesses or points of interest to each other where each ID represents the same place
  • Places Global DatabaseÂ APIÂ - 55 million entities in 47 countries
  • Places Global Place AttributesÂ APIÂ - The latest schema for the global places dataset
  • Places ResolveÂ APIÂ - Makes partial records complete, matches one entity against another, and assists in de-duping and normalizing datasets
  • Places RestaurantsÂ APIÂ - Core places attributes in addition to 43 extended attributes on 800,000+ restaurants, bars, and casual eateries including datatypes such as cuisine, ratings, hours of operations, and price

Tied with SimpleGeo and Factual isÂ InfoChimps. InfoChimps is a data marketplace player with some very strong location and places services:

  • Wikipedia ArticlesÂ - Correlate Wikipedia articles with geographic locations
  • Business Places by LocationaryÂ - The Business Places by Locationary API delivers quality business information based on your geographically defined query
  • Foursquare PlacesÂ - The Foursquare Places API delivers uniquely rich information about venues, worldwide.
  • Geonames PlacesÂ - The Geonames Places API locates all places within a specified area. Places are any geographic points that can be named
  • NCDC WeatherÂ - The NCDC Weather API provides detailed weather data based on your geographically defined query. Weather data points for your query may include dew point, precipitation, snow depth, temperature, visibility, and wind speed details
  • American Community Survey (Topline)Â - The 2009 American Community Survey (ACS) Topline API provides basic demographic data based on your geographically defined query
  • American Community Survey (Drilldown)- The 2009 American Community Survey (ACS) Drilldown API provides detailed demographic data based on your geographically defined query
  • Core Geographic RegionsÂ - The Core Geographic Regions API delivers detailed geodata for any geographically defined query, worldwide
  • Zillow NeighborhoodsÂ - Zillow Neighborhoods retrieves geo data pertaining to neighborhoods within defined geometric parameters
  • Digital Element IP Intelligence DemographicsÂ - A geolocation API for all your demographics needs. Search by IP address to return data about a geographical area, including number of households, gender, age groups and language
  • Digital Element IP Intelligence DomainsÂ - A reverse IP lookup API with 5 fields of search results, all customized to your IP query. Search by IP address to return data about the domain, company, ISP, NAICS industry code and proxy type for an IP
  • Digital Element IP Intelligence GeolocationÂ - A geolocation API with 20 fields of search results, all customized to your IP query. Search by IP address to return data about a geographical area, including country, region, city, internet connection speed
  • Geocoding APIÂ - The Geocoding API is a powerful and useful tool that provides location information for any given address in the United States. Geocoding is a process that assigns geographic data (ie, latitude and longitude) to an address
  • Latitude Longitude and Zip Code Conversions -Â This API returns approximated latitude/longitude centroids for a given zip code, along with the relative city, state, and county

Then moving out of pure data playersÂ YelpÂ has always been centered around reviews, and more recently, with version 2.0 of their API moved to be centered around the businesses. Yelp has two places APIs:

  • Search APIÂ - Searches for Businesses
  • Business APIÂ - Returns full details of businesses

Another player in the space isÂ Fwix. Fwix has a different approach to places, trying to geotag the web. Fwix offers six places and location APIs:

  • Geotagger APIÂ - Returns places geotagged to a given web page
  • Content APIÂ - Returns geotagged content in or near a location
  • Categories APIÂ - Returns the list of canonical place categories
  • Location APIÂ - Returns geographic data for a latitude/longitude point
  • Places APIÂ - Return, Submit and Delete a list of businesses for a given location

After Fwix I found a couple of other mapping, location and places data services:

  • PushPinÂ - The Pushpin Identify Service is a REST service that takes geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude) and resolves them to named locations on the earth
  • 43 PlacesÂ -Â Allows users build 43 Places by adding places, asking questions, giving travel advice, uploading pictures of their favorite places and writing stories about the places theyâ€™ve been and want to go.
  • MaxMind GeoIPÂ® City DatabaseÂ -Â Determine country, state/region, city, US postal code, US area code, metro code, latitude, and longitude information for IP addresses worldwide.
  • CompassÂ -Â Allows access to a database of 16 million business establishments in the USA.

These providers either didnâ€™t have clear market share or started deviating into other parallel universes of content and services to location and places, so Iâ€™m going to stop here.

These 17 places and location API providers are a lot to process. Â I want to spend some time getting a handle on the types of services they offer, before I dive into the peripheral services as well as the players that have less market share. But in my style, Iâ€™ll keep posting my findings as I pull them together.
